TextEquiv.Unicode: that you have them in singular love
through love for their worke sake. Be
at peace with them. Let so much ther
fore of the church goods as is sufficient
be given unto the ministers & teachers,
so farre forth as honest necessity requi
reth. And thus much have we spoken
concerning the proportion that is due
unto pastors,
In times past the seconde parte of
ecclesiasticall goods was allotted unto
clearkes. And clearkes are the harvest
of Pastors, studlous of divinity , and
wholly disposed to the holy ministery,
And forasmuch as these have dedica
ted theselves and all that they have
wholly to the Church & the ministerie
thereof, it is most fit that they shoulde
be nourished & mainteined by the costs
of the Church. But it is convenient
they be nourished meanly, who ought
to be an erample of meave and thrifty
living to other
For to bee brought up delicately,
doth nothing agree with the ministe
ries of the Church. And therefore, A
mos founde fault that the Nararites
dranke wine, for that he meant that
drunkardes did not mainteine the
church, but utterly destroy it. Of which
matter wee spake in another place,
Moreover, it is fit that due portions be
payde to Priests, schoolemaisters, scho
lers, and to all other ecclesiasticall per
sons whatsoever
Finally the third part of ecclesiasti
call goodes are appoynted for the poore,
And ther are divers fortes of poore
folke: as widowes, pupils, orphanes, &
infantes cast out (whose parentes are
not known. Also they that are worne
with old age, and spent with diseases,
Ther are insinite kindes of diseases,
whereof the most grievous are theser
leprosie, furie, and madnes, the french
pockes, or the scabbe of India or Na

that you have them in singular love through love for their worke sake. Be at peace with them. Let so much ther fore of the church goods as is sufficient be given unto the ministers & teachers, so farre forth as honest necessity requi reth. And thus much have we spoken concerning the proportion that is due unto pastors, In times past the seconde parte of ecclesiasticall goods was allotted unto clearkes. And clearkes are the harvest of Pastors, studlous of divinity , and wholly disposed to the holy ministery, And forasmuch as these have dedica ted theselves and all that they have wholly to the Church & the ministerie thereof, it is most fit that they shoulde be nourished & mainteined by the costs of the Church. But it is convenient they be nourished meanly, who ought to be an erample of meave and thrifty living to other For to bee brought up delicately, doth nothing agree with the ministe ries of the Church. And therefore, A mos founde fault that the Nararites dranke wine, for that he meant that drunkardes did not mainteine the church, but utterly destroy it. Of which matter wee spake in another place, Moreover, it is fit that due portions be payde to Priests, schoolemaisters, scho lers, and to all other ecclesiasticall per sons whatsoever Finally the third part of ecclesiasti call goodes are appoynted for the poore, And ther are divers fortes of poore folke: as widowes, pupils, orphanes, & infantes cast out (whose parentes are not known. Also they that are worne with old age, and spent with diseases, Ther are insinite kindes of diseases, whereof the most grievous are theser leprosie, furie, and madnes, the french pockes, or the scabbe of India or Na
ples, the palsey, the goute, and a great
many moe. Ther are not onely poore
men borne within the lande, but also
straungers that are banished their
countrey and home for righteousnesse
sake, and for the worde of God. There
are other who are not yet come to er
treme poverty, but are even now rea
dy to fall into it, so that if they be not
holpen a litle with ready money, they
by & by come to be kept by the church
bore. Againe, there are some that are
consumed by imprisonmet, by warres,
by great Clouds of waters, by fire, and
divers other mishappes, as by hayle,
frostes, & other stormes and distempe
ratures of the ayre,
Of all whose health and safegard
the Lorde willed us to bee mindetul,
whereas hee saith, that whatsoever
wee bestowe uppon the poore, wee
bestowe it uppon him. Therefore if
wee despise and regarde not the poore,
without al doubt wee despise and neg
lect even our Lorde God himelfe in
the poore. Wee ought of duety to sue
cour the poore of our owne good will,
by counsell, comfort, medicines, cures,
money, meate, drink, clothes, lodging.
succouring, and by anye meanes else
that wee may, and in all such matters
and cases, as they sh all have neede of
our helpe. It so bee the Church goodes
are not susficient to performe all this
at the full, then let the aboundance of
all other good faithfull people supplye
their want. But if there bee goods suf
ficient in store laid up, which have byn
in times past cotributed by the libera
lity of the godly, which notwithstading
through negligence or wickednes of
governors are taken away, so that the
necessity of the poore cannot thereby be
succoured, for that cause truely moste
shary tempests of infelicities are pow
red forth both upon common wealths

ples, the palsey, the goute, and a great many moe. Ther are not onely poore men borne within the lande, but also straungers that are banished their countrey and home for righteousnesse sake, and for the worde of God. There are other who are not yet come to er treme poverty, but are even now rea dy to fall into it, so that if they be not holpen a litle with ready money, they by & by come to be kept by the church bore. Againe, there are some that are consumed by imprisonmet, by warres, by great Clouds of waters, by fire, and divers other mishappes, as by hayle, frostes, & other stormes and distempe ratures of the ayre, Of all whose health and safegard the Lorde willed us to bee mindetul, whereas hee saith, that whatsoever wee bestowe uppon the poore, wee bestowe it uppon him. Therefore if wee despise and regarde not the poore, without al doubt wee despise and neg lect even our Lorde God himelfe in the poore. Wee ought of duety to sue cour the poore of our owne good will, by counsell, comfort, medicines, cures, money, meate, drink, clothes, lodging. succouring, and by anye meanes else that wee may, and in all such matters and cases, as they sh all have neede of our helpe. It so bee the Church goodes are not susficient to performe all this at the full, then let the aboundance of all other good faithfull people supplye their want. But if there bee goods suf ficient in store laid up, which have byn in times past cotributed by the libera lity of the godly, which notwithstading through negligence or wickednes of governors are taken away, so that the necessity of the poore cannot thereby be succoured, for that cause truely moste shary tempests of infelicities are pow red forth both upon common wealths
